title: Assignment 1
text:
data(anscombe)  # Load Anscombe's data
# View(anscombe) # View the data
summary(anscombe)

       x1             x2             x3             x4           y1        
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   : 4.0   Min.   : 4.0   Min.   : 8   Min.   : 4.260

summary(anscombe)

       x1             x2             x3             x4           y1        
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   : 4.0   Min.   : 4.0   Min.   : 8   Min.   : 4.260  
 1st Qu.: 6.5   1st Qu.: 6.5   1st Qu.: 6.5   1st Qu.: 8   1st Qu.: 6.315

# Create four model objects
lm1 <- lm(y1 ~ x1, data=anscombe)
summary(lm1)


Call:
lm(formula = y1 ~ x1, data = anscombe)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-1.92127 -0.45577 -0.04136  0.70941  1.83882 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)   
(Intercept)   3.0001     1.1247   2.667  0.02573 * 
x1            0.5001     0.1179   4.241  0.00217 **
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 1.237 on 9 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.6665,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.6295 
F-statistic: 17.99 on 1 and 9 DF,  p-value: 0.00217

lm2 <- lm(y2 ~ x2, data=anscombe)
summary(lm2)

            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)

x2             0.500      0.118   4.239  0.00218 **
---

Multiple R-squared:  0.6662,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.6292 
F-statistic: 17.97 on 1 and 9 DF,  p-value: 0.002179

lm3 <- lm(y3 ~ x3, data=anscombe)
summary(lm3)

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-1.1586 -0.6146 -0.2303  0.1540  3.2411 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)   
(Intercept)   3.0025     1.1245   2.670  0.02562 *

F-statistic:    18 on 1 and 9 DF,  p-value: 0.002165

plot(anscombe$x1,anscombe$y1)
abline(coefficients(lm1))



plot(anscombe$x2,anscombe$y2)
abline(coefficients(lm2))



plot(anscombe$x3,anscombe$y3)
abline(coefficients(lm3))



plot(anscombe$x4,anscombe$y4)
abline(coefficients(lm4))





## Fancy version (per help file)

ff <- y ~ x
mods <- setNames(as.list(1:4), paste0("lm", 1:4))

# Plot using for loop
for(i in 1:4) {
  ff[2:3] <- lapply(paste0(c("y","x"), i), as.name)
  ## or   ff[[2]] <- as.name(paste0("y", i))
  ##      ff[[3]] <- as.name(paste0("x", i))
  mods[[i]] <- lmi <- lm(ff, data = anscombe)
  print(anova(lmi))
}

Analysis of Variance Table

Response: y1
          Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value  Pr(>F)   
x1         1 27.510 27.5100   17.99 0.00217 **
Residuals  9 13.763  1.5292                   
---

Response: y2
          Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)   
x2         1 27.500 27.5000  17.966 0.002179 **

---

Analysis of Variance Table

Response: y3
          Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)

Residuals  9 13.756  1.5285                    
---

Analysis of Variance Table

Response: y4
          Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)   
x4         1 27.490 27.4900  18.003 0.002165 **
Residuals  9 13.742  1.5269                    
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

                  lm1      lm2       lm3       lm4
(Intercept) 3.0000909 3.000909 3.0024545 3.0017273
x1          0.5000909 0.500000 0.4997273 0.4999091

$lm1
             Estimate Std. Error  t value    Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept) 3.0000909  1.1247468 2.667348 0.025734051
x1          0.5000909  0.1179055 4.241455 0.002169629

$lm2
            Estimate Std. Error  t value    Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept) 3.000909  1.1253024 2.666758 0.025758941
x2          0.500000  0.1179637 4.238590 0.002178816

$lm3
             Estimate Std. Error  t value    Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept) 3.0024545  1.1244812 2.670080 0.025619109
x3          0.4997273  0.1178777 4.239372 0.002176305

$lm4
             Estimate Std. Error  t value    Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept) 3.0017273  1.1239211 2.670763 0.025590425
x4          0.4999091  0.1178189 4.243028 0.002164602

# Preparing for the plots
op <- par(mfrow = c(2, 2), mar = 0.1+c(4,4,1,1), oma =  c(0, 0, 2, 0))


# Plot charts using for loop
for(i in 1:4) {
  ff[2:3] <- lapply(paste0(c("y","x"), i), as.name)
  plot(ff, data = anscombe, col = "red", pch = 21, bg = "orange", cex = 1.2,
       xlim = c(3, 19), ylim = c(3, 13))
  abline(mods[[i]], col = "blue")
}









mtext("Anscombe's 4 Regression data sets", outer = TRUE, cex = 1.5)



par(op)

title: Assignment 1
text:
Examples of Generative Art
Generative art is a form of digital art that is generated using algorithms and machines. Below are a few examples of this type of art.



Generative Art by Manolo Gamboa Naon


Naon is an Argentinian artist who utilizes algorithmic tools such as Processing to create art.



Generative Art by Anders Hoff


This is part of Hoff’s project “Inconvergent”, which explores the complex behavior that can occur from systems with simple rules.



Sprawl by Mark J. Stock


This generative artwork by Stock compares two seemingly different growth patterns.
Source for Images

title: Assignment 1
text:
Run of “Fall.R”

library(gsubfn)

Loading required package: proto


Warning in fun(libname, pkgname): couldn't connect to display
"/private/tmp/com.apple.launchd.5SMJirzgbS/org.xquartz:0"

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.0     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.1     ✔ tibble    3.1.8
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.1     


── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the ]8;;http://conflicted.r-lib.org/conflicted package]8;; to force all conflicts to become errors



# Define elements in plant art
# Each image corresponds to a different axiom, rules, angle and depth
# Leaf of Fall
axiom="X"
rules=list("X"="F-[[X]+X]+F[+FX]-X", "F"="FF")
angle=22.5
depth=6


for (i in 1:depth) axiom=gsubfn(".", rules, axiom)

actions=str_extract_all(axiom, "\\d*\\+|\\d*\\-|F|L|R|\\[|\\]|\\|") %>% unlist

status=data.frame(x=numeric(0), y=numeric(0), alfa=numeric(0))
points=data.frame(x1 = 0, y1 = 0, x2 = NA, y2 = NA, alfa=90, depth=1)


# Generating data
# Note: may take a minute or two

for (action in actions)
{
  if (action=="F")
  {
    x=points[1, "x1"]+cos(points[1, "alfa"]*(pi/180))
    y=points[1, "y1"]+sin(points[1, "alfa"]*(pi/180))
    points[1,"x2"]=x
    points[1,"y2"]=y
    data.frame(x1 = x, y1 = y, x2 = NA, y2 = NA,
               alfa=points[1, "alfa"],
               depth=points[1,"depth"]) %>% rbind(points)->points
  }
  if (action %in% c("+", "-")){
    alfa=points[1, "alfa"]
    points[1, "alfa"]=eval(parse(text=paste0("alfa",action, angle)))
  }
  if(action=="["){
    data.frame(x=points[1, "x1"], y=points[1, "y1"], alfa=points[1, "alfa"]) %>%
      rbind(status) -> status
    points[1, "depth"]=points[1, "depth"]+1
  }

  if(action=="]"){
    depth=points[1, "depth"]
    points[-1,]->points
    data.frame(x1=status[1, "x"], y1=status[1, "y"], x2=NA, y2=NA,
               alfa=status[1, "alfa"],
               depth=depth-1) %>%
      rbind(points) -> points
    status[-1,]->status
  }
}


ggplot() +
  geom_segment(aes(x = x1, y = y1, xend = x2, yend = y2),
               lineend = "round",
               color="yellowgreen", # Set your own Fall color?
               data=na.omit(points)) +
  coord_fixed(ratio = 1) +
  theme_void() # No grid nor axes

title: Assignment 1
text:
Critique of a Chart/Graph

The graph shown above was taken from the article “In the ICU, doctors see rise in Covid cases but less severe disease”. There are a few parts of the graph that make it less effective in being a good visual. For instance, the part that adds the territories and the color label for the % change for hospital admissions for COVID-19 seems almost unnecessary. The graph already provides the labels for each of the states so perhaps the territories are to provide a summary. However, 3 of the 7 territories have insufficient data so it seems extra to even include this. Furthermore, this graph has no title and instead provides a description towards the bottom. A reader is more likely to look at the top first to understand what the graph’s information is. It would be better to move the same description/title to the top of the graph so that it stands out more. Next, the color choice for the different range of percentages could be a little better. For example, for both the ‘substantial increase’ and ‘moderate increase’ labels the color is orange-like (one is darker than the other). While using the same colors with different tones is common for charts and graphs, this color choice doesn’t seem to distinguish the areas that well. Finally, the words for each of the labels on the key would be easier to read if they were placed vertically instead of being slanted.

title: EPPS 6356 Website - Rishika Katamneni
text: This is Rishika Katamneni’s personal website for the EPPS 6356 course (Data Visualization).

title: Collection of Projects
text:
Log Cluster Healthcheck Output to PostgreSQL database
This project is implemented using Ansible to create and update a table in a PostgreSQL database from output text. Various Ansible modules are utilized such as postgresql_table, postgresql_copy, etc. to create a table and copy data from a text file to the table.


Bot or Not? Twitter Bot Detection Using Logistic and Multilayer Perceptron ModelsBot or Not? Twitter Bot Detection Using Logistic and Multilayer Perceptron Models
The purpose of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of two different machine learning classification models to distinguish whether a given Twitter account is that of a real user or that of a bot account.


Implementing a Reinforcement Learning Algorithm for Playing the Game Blackjack using Tabular Q-learning
In this study, a reinforcement learning algorithm was developed for playing the game blackjack using tabular type Q-Learning. The proposed approach was assessed using the OpenAI Gymnasium’s (formerly OpenAI Gym) library for the Toy Text environment specifically focused on the game Blackjack.


Road Lane Detection
This project is implemented using Python and OpenCV to detect lanes on a road and mark stop signs with a blue circle.


Transfer Learning on Flowers Dataset
This project is implemented using Python and TensorFlow to classify flowers into 13 different types by utilizing transfer learning from a pre-trained network (MobileNet V2).


Perspective Transform on Bank Check Images
This project is implemented using Python and OpenCV for a bank check scanner to transform the images of checks from different camera orientations and positions.

title: About Me
text:
A student at the University of Texas at Dallas pursuing a master’s degree (M.S.) in Artificial Intelligence/Computational Modeling and Machine Learning. In the Summer of 2022, I worked as a cloud integration engineer intern at Ericsson and currently work as a software engineer at L3Harris Technologies.
I have substantial leadership, technical experience, and excellent collaborative skills. Also, I am hardworking, reliable, organized, and punctual with a team-oriented mindset. I have proficient experience in Java, Python, C, C++, data structures, object-oriented programming, and statistical modeling.
